title: Trinite f-ligatures
content:
I’m considering to buy the font Trinité (No. 2) from Enschedé ( [http://www.teff.nl/fonts/trinite/trinite.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20070808131217/http:/www.teff.nl/fonts/trinite/trinite.html "http://www.teff.nl/fonts/trinite/trinite.html")), but as far as I can see it has no fi (or other f-) ligature(s). I find this very strange, since I’ve seen examples of Trinité in use with the fi- and fl-ligatures. The other fonts from Enschedé seems to have several f-ligatures.

Does anyone have a point of view on this? Thank you!

 [‹ Does anyone not much like reading letterpress Bembo?](http://web.archive.org/web/20070808131217/http:/typophile.com/node/19299 "Go to previous forum topic") ["Schoolbook" Alternates ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20070808131217/http:/typophile.com/node/19354 "Go to next forum topic")
author: fredrik.fabrikk

comments.content:
There is no need for separate ligatures in Trinité.  
The f seamlessy closes up to the i, j, l, h, k and b  
if the glyphs are set without letterspacing.

I tought Trinité was so well designed that it didn’t need any ligatures. With the n°2 the stem of the lowercase f always covers the point of the i.

You can see it clearly on the sample sheet ( [http://www.teff.nl/fonts/trinite/pdf/trinite\_a3\_print-600.pdf](http://web.archive.org/web/20070808131217/http:/www.teff.nl/fonts/trinite/pdf/trinite_a3_print-600.pdf "http://www.teff.nl/fonts/trinite/pdf/trinite\_a3\_print-600.pdf")).

_With the n°2 the stem of the lowercase f always covers the point of the i._

So don’t use it to typeset Turkish :)
Thank you very much! That’s all I needed to know.
